Early Access Review
								This is my favourite game featuring interstellar narwhals. It should be yours too.Narwhals (Monodon monoceros) are an aquatic mammal that live in the icy Arctic Ocean. In Old Norse nár means "corpse" for the animal's mottled grey skin colour resembled drowned sailors. It's scientific name is derived from Greek, meaning "one-tooth one-horn." It is this horn that is the defining characteristic of this majestic beast. Growing up to three metres in length the narwhal tusk is actually a tooth that pierces through the lip and protrudes past the upper jaw. The general consensus among scientific community is that this tusk is a secondary sex characteristic to garner attraction from all the lady narwhals (size does matter).Not alike their earthly narwhal cousins, the galactic starwhal also features such a tusk but this is not a tusk to attract mates, it is a tusk to destroy enemies (size does matter). The goal of game is simple, using your tusk, just the tip, you must impale the heart of your opponents. Only a strike to the heart will yield any damage and the game has a cool bullet-time slow-motion effect every time a heart is within range of being pierced.  It is a  hectic, tense, and often awkward struggle. As of right now it is an early access game but it is fully playable with only more content and game-modes to look forward to in the future. Its not really a game you can enjoy by yourself and there is no online multiplayer although that may change heading forward. The game shines with local co-op; best played with four players. I had no issues connecting and using four 360 controllers. It may lack in lasting appeal but if you have a few friends over and are looking for a quick, fun, and competitive gaming experience, look no further, looks to the stars.

The goal of the game is to attack your opponent's heart whith your Starwhal's horn (only the tip of the horn does damage, hence the "Just The Tip" in the name of the game) while avoiding having your heart attacked. The game does a slo-mo anytime that a player gets his/hers horn close to another player's heart, so every attack or dodge feels epic (and this allows all players to really see what's going on and think about their next moves). You wil learn how to use your Starwhal to stab an opponent, pin him down, fling him away, bait him, etc. And all those actions are not predetermined moves, but rather actions derived from the mobility of your Starwahl and the physics of the game.   The game keeps getting more content and feels very stable, despite being in Early Access (I have not encountered any bug or glitch). untill now it lacks online multiplayer, so it's a local multiplayer experience only. But it's one of the best local multiplayer games I have ever played (next to Super Smash Bros. Melee, Castle Crashers, Battle Block Theater). If you have a couple of controllers and competitive people next to you, play this and enjoy a great experience. I find that even against the bots the game is awesome, as the AI is very good and seems to have some behavior variation. I gave it 9/10 as the game is still in Early Access and thus, it lacks some options (like the ability to create custom games, choose songs, maybe a level editor, more content). But so far it feels that this is already a solid game that is in the phase of getting more content. I don't doubt that it would become a 10/10 when the final release comes out.

"Space narwhales stab their hearts each other in many arenas"Starwhal is a roguelike PvP swim'n'stab game with a pretty cool soundtrack. The main characters are in free nature very rare narwhales which are here colored and flow in space for the casual playing and fun.It has basically two gamemodes. 1. Challenge mode is like a skilled timemode to run through labrinths. 2. Versus mode is a PvP arena upto 4 players, but just local Co-op.Though you can have some fun for a few hours with the wonky controls and beating your Steam friends as ghost whales in challenge mode. But then the stimula is mostly over. No locked maps to unlock, no other excitement. Just earning medals and die trying over and over again. If you are somehow finished with the Challenge mode then comes the really most grinding part: The Versus mode. Naturally you play against yourself if you don't have your friends at home all the time. But you have to do it many many times to get the extraordinary high amount of kills (10k in classic 32k in score) for the achievements. And even if they are similiar to do (stab other whales into their hearts) they don't count for each other. That's quite annoying to have such an artificial playtime extender in there.My conclusion: Starwhale could be a casual and fun game. But in reality it demands too much time for grinding some achievements. Also it has just local co-op and is pretty high priced unless you can get it for cheap in a bundle.

Starwhal - Fighting for LOVE in SPACE.Starwhal is the Magnum Opus of our time. Across the vast, cold darkness of space brightly colored Cetaceans murder eachother to trance-like vibes and the squeal of echolocation for the honor of being the only Starwhal standing.More accurately, Starwhal is a multiplayer, 2D game where you're a space narwhal, and your goal is to stab other starwhal's in their giant beating hearts for points.There's a ton of levels, stage traps, the controls are wonky and it makes a great party game. I've yet to have someone sit down and not have fun with it. There's a ton of customization options so you can tell which starwhal is yours too, from lightsabers to sushi wraps.On the downside some of the level traps/hazards aren't very fun and are more distracting from the game's fun side. There isn't really much fun playing single-player eitherRating: 4/5. It's a very, very good party game you won't spend much time on your own on.Pros:Large variety of levelsHigh-level Narwhal customizationWiggle PhysicsGreat for Parties/get-togethersNarwhals in spaceCons:Kinda boring without other people to play withSome of the stage traps aren't very fun, even if they're creative.
